LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Section titled “LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors”

Building AI agents and workflows typically requires integrating multiple APIs, handling different response formats, and managing provider-specific quirks. LLMTornado by lofcz simplifies this complexity with a unified .NET SDK that supports 25+ AI providers and vector databases out of the box.

What is LLMTornado?

Section titled “What is LLMTornado?”

LLMTornado is a provider-agnostic .NET SDK that empowers developers to build, orchestrate, and deploy AI agents and workflows. Whether you’re building a simple chatbot or an autonomous coding agent, LLM Tornado provides the tools you need with unparalleled integration into the AI ecosystem.

GitHub Repository: lofcz/LLMTornado Official Website: llmtornado.ai License: MIT NuGet Downloads: 70,000+ Language: C# / .NET

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Use Any Provider

Section titled “1. Use Any Provider”

Built-in connectors to 25+ AI providers with no dependencies on first-party SDKs:

CategoryProviders
Major LLMsOpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Azure, Cohere, Mistral, xAI (Grok)
Fast & AffordableGroq, DeepSeek, DeepInfra, Perplexity, OpenRouter
SpecializedMoonshotAI, Alibaba Cloud, Blablador, Z.ai, Voyage
LocalvLLM, Ollama, LocalAI

2. First-Class Local Deployments

Section titled “2. First-Class Local Deployments”

Run with vLLM, Ollama, or LocalAI with integrated support for request transformations.

3. Agent Orchestration

Section titled “3. Agent Orchestration”

Coordinate specialist agents with three core concepts:

  • Orchestrator (graph) - Define agent workflows
  • Runner (node) - Execute agent tasks
  • Advancer (edge) - Connect agents

Features include handoffs, parallel execution, Mermaid export, and builder pattern.

4. Cutting-Edge Protocols

Section titled “4. Cutting-Edge Protocols”
  • MCP (Model Context Protocol) - Connect agents to data sources and tools
  • A2A (Agent-to-Agent) - Enable collaboration between AI agents across platforms
  • Skills - Dynamically load folders of instructions and scripts for specialized tasks

5. Vector Databases

Section titled “5. Vector Databases”

Built-in connectors to:

  • Chroma
  • PgVector
  • Pinecone
  • Faiss
  • QDrant

6. Enterprise Ready

Section titled “6. Enterprise Ready”
  • Guardrails framework
  • Request preview and transformation
  • Open Telemetry support
  • Stable APIs
  • Microsoft.Extensions.AI interoperability

Section titled “Tool/Function Calling”

Section titled “Agent Orchestration Example”

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

1. Multi-Provider Chat Application

Section titled “1. Multi-Provider Chat Application”

Build a chat app that seamlessly switches between providers based on cost, speed, or capability requirements.

2. RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)

Section titled “2. RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)”

Combine LLM Tornado with vector database connectors for document Q&A:

3. Agent Workflows

Section titled “3. Agent Workflows”

Orchestrate multiple specialist agents for complex tasks:

  • Research agent gathers information
  • Analysis agent processes findings
  • Writer agent creates final output

4. Enterprise Applications

Section titled “4. Enterprise Applications”
  • Guardrails for content moderation
  • Open Telemetry for observability
  • Microsoft.Extensions.AI integration with Semantic Kernel

Real-World Projects Built with LLM Tornado

Community & Support

Section titled “Community & Support”
  • NuGet: 70,000+ installs
  • Monthly Usage: Processing 100B+ tokens in commercial projects
  • Test Coverage: 350+ tests
  • Featured in: .NET AI Community Standup by Microsoft
  • Used by: Microsoft in Generative AI for Beginners .NET

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

Loki Mode: Transform PRDs into Revenue-Generating Products with 37 AI Agents

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Loki Mode: Transform PRDs into Revenue-Generating Products with 37 AI Agents

Section titled “Loki Mode: Transform PRDs into Revenue-Generating Products with 37 AI Agents”

“Transform a PRD into a fully deployed, revenue-generating product with zero human intervention.”

What if you could turn a single product requirements document into a complete, deployed startup—without writing a single line of code yourself? Meet Loki Mode, a Claude Code skill that orchestrates 37 specialized AI agents across 6 swarms to autonomously build, deploy, and operate entire businesses.

What is Loki Mode?

Section titled “What is Loki Mode?”

Loki Mode is a multi-agent autonomous startup system for Claude Code. Just say “Loki Mode” and provide a PRD. The system handles everything:

Created by asklokesh, this ambitious project pushes the boundaries of what’s possible with AI agents working in concert.

The Architecture: 37 Agents, 6 Swarms

Section titled “The Architecture: 37 Agents, 6 Swarms”

Loki Mode organizes its AI workforce into specialized swarms, each with a specific domain focus:

Engineering Swarm (8 agents)

Section titled “Engineering Swarm (8 agents)”
  • eng-frontend - Frontend implementation
  • eng-backend - Backend services
  • eng-database - Database architecture
  • eng-mobile - Mobile development
  • eng-api - API design and implementation
  • eng-qa - Quality assurance
  • eng-perf - Performance optimization
  • eng-infra - Infrastructure setup

Operations Swarm (8 agents)

Usage

Section titled “Usage”

Autonomous Runner (Recommended)

Section titled “Autonomous Runner (Recommended)”

The autonomous runner handles everything:

The runner:

  1. Checks all prerequisites (Claude CLI, Python, Git, etc.)
  2. Verifies skill installation
  3. Initializes the .loki/ directory
  4. Starts a status monitor (updates every 5 seconds)
  5. Starts Claude Code with live output
  6. Auto-resumes on rate limits or interruptions
  7. Continues until completion or max retries

3. InfrastructureProvision cloud, CI/CD, monitoring
4. DevelopmentImplement with TDD, parallel code review

6. DeploymentBlue-green deploy, auto-rollback on errors
7. BusinessMarketing, sales, legal, support setup
8. GrowthContinuous optimization, A/B testing, feedback loops

SeverityAction
Critical/High/MediumBlock. Fix immediately. Re-review.
LowAdd // TODO(review): ... comment, continue
CosmeticAdd // FIXME(nitpick): ... comment, continue

Agentic Signal: Visual AI Workflow Automation Platform with Local LLM Integration

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Explore Agentic Signal by Code Forge Temple — a visual drag-and-drop AI workflow automation platform that runs entirely locally with Ollama integration. Build intelligent workflows without coding, with no cloud dependencies required.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Agentic Signal is an open-source visual AI workflow automation platform created by Code Forge Temple. It enables users to build intelligent, AI-powered workflows using a drag-and-drop interface while running everything locally on their machine.

What sets Agentic Signal apart is its commitment to privacy-first local execution. By integrating with Ollama, it allows you to harness the power of large language models without sending your data to the cloud. This makes it ideal for processing sensitive documents, building personal automation workflows, or simply maintaining full control over your AI interactions.

Repository: code-forge-temple/agentic-signal Website: agentic-signal.com

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Visual Drag-and-Drop InterfaceBuild workflows visually using React Flow — no coding required
Node-Based ArchitectureConnect data sources, AI processors, and outputs seamlessly
Real-time ExecutionSee your workflows run in real-time with live data flow visualization
Ollama IntegrationRun AI models locally with privacy and control
Tool CallingAI agents can execute functions and access external APIs
Structured OutputJSON schema validation for reliable AI responses
Conversation MemoryMaintain context across workflow executions
Browser AutomationWeb scraping and automation via Google Chrome integration

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Agentic Signal provides pre-built releases for Windows, macOS, and Linux:

  1. Download the release package for your operating system from GitHub Releases

  2. Install Google Chrome — required for web scraping and browser automation nodes

  3. Install and Run Agentic Signal

    • Run the installer and follow the prompts
    • Windows users: When launching for the first time, your antivirus may scan the app (the installer is unsigned)

  4. Configure Ollama

    • Make sure Ollama is running with CORS enabled for the Windows app
    • Configure the Ollama Host in app settings

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Required

Section titled “Required”

  • Google Chrome — Required for browser automation and web scraping nodes

    • Download from google.com/chrome

  • Ollama — Local LLM runtime

Optional (for Google Services Integration)

Section titled “Optional (for Google Services Integration)”

If you want to use Gmail, Google Drive, or Google Calendar nodes, you’ll need to set up OAuth2 credentials:

  1. Go to Google Cloud Console
  2. Create a new project or select existing one
  3. Enable the APIs you want to use (Gmail, Drive, Calendar)
  4. Create OAuth 2.0 credentials (Desktop app)
  5. Download the credentials JSON file

Node Types and Architecture

Section titled “Node Types and Architecture”

Agentic Signal uses a node-based workflow architecture where each node represents a processing unit:

Node Structure

Section titled “Node Structure”
  • Input/Output Data Connectors — Connect data flow between nodes
  • Tool Connector — Additional connectors for AI tools and functions
  • Timer Connector — Schedule automatic execution at intervals
  • Settings — Configure node-specific options
  • Error Logs — View errors when processing fails
  • Output — View processed results
  • Run — Manually trigger workflow execution

Available Node Types

Section titled “Available Node Types”
Node TypeDescription
Data SourceInput data from files, APIs, or manual entry
AI Data ProcessingProcess data with local LLMs via Ollama
AI ToolExecute function calling with AI agents
HTTP DataMake REST API calls to external services
JSON ReformatterTransform and restructure JSON data
ChartVisualize data with various chart types
Data ValidationValidate data against schemas
Data Flow SpyDebug and inspect data flow
Timer NodeSchedule periodic executions

Section titled “Example 1: AI-Powered Email Assistant”

  2. Uses local LLM to categorize and prioritize (AI Data Processing)
  3. Generates summary responses (AI Tool)
  4. Saves to Google Drive for reference (HTTP Data)

Section titled “Example 2: Research Automation”

Build a workflow that:

  1. Takes a research topic as input (Data Source)
  2. Searches multiple sources (DuckDuckGo, Brave Search nodes)
  3. Extracts and summarizes findings with local LLM (AI Data Processing)

  4. Display formatted output (Chart or Display node)

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

App Won’t Start (Windows)

Section titled “App Won’t Start (Windows)”

If the app is slow or unresponsive on first launch:

  1. Wait for antivirus scan to complete
  2. Close and restart Agentic Signal
  3. Add exception to antivirus if needed

Ollama Connection Failed

Section titled “Ollama Connection Failed”
  1. Verify Ollama is running: ollama list
  2. Check CORS is enabled: OLLAMA_ORIGINS="*" ollama serve
  3. Verify Ollama Host in app settings is http://localhost:11434

Browser Automation Not Working

Section titled “Browser Automation Not Working”
  1. Verify Chrome is installed
  2. Check Chrome executable path in app settings
  3. Make sure Chrome version is up-to-date

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Start Simple — Begin with basic workflows before adding complexity
  2. Use Appropriate Models — Choose Ollama models based on your task (faster models for simple tasks, more capable for complex reasoning)
  3. Modular Design — Break complex workflows into smaller, reusable components
  4. Test Iteratively — Run and test each node as you build
  5. Monitor Performance — Use Data Flow Spy to debug bottlenecks

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Section titled “KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling”

In the world of AI research assistants, most tools focus on quick, one-shot responses. KestrelAI takes a different approach—it’s a local-first research assistant that self-schedules and executes support tasks over long horizons, allowing you to stay focused on complex, novel work while it handles mechanical tasks in the background.

What is KestrelAI?

Section titled “What is KestrelAI?”

Kestrel is a local-first research assistant designed for long-running research tasks. What makes it unique:

  • Self-Scheduling: Automatically plans and schedules work, tracks progress, and pivots when stalled
  • Long-Horizon Execution: Runs for hours or days, providing auditable checkpoints for review
  • Local-First: Built to run on small LLMs (1-7B) via Ollama—laptop/desktop friendly
  • Source Provenance: Maintains clear records of consulted searches and their impact on findings

GitHub Repository: dankeg/KestrelAI Author: Ganesh Danke License: MIT

The Problem Kestrel Solves

Section titled “The Problem Kestrel Solves”

When doing deep research work, you often encounter time-consuming mechanical tasks:

  • Comparing tools and frameworks
  • Gathering real-world usage examples
  • Extracting performance claims from documentation
  • Assembling comprehensive comparisons

These tasks interrupt your flow on the actual novel work. Kestrel handles this background research, surfacing organized evidence when you need it.

Example Use Case

Section titled “Example Use Case”

Imagine you’re interpreting a frontier research paper and planning a novel study. You need to decide between Polars vs. pandas vs. Spark for your data processing.

Instead of spending hours manually researching, you tell Kestrel:

“Compare Polars, pandas, and Spark for data processing. Gather real-world usage, performance benchmarks, and use case recommendations.”

Kestrel then runs in the background:

  1. Searches for documentation and benchmarks
  2. Filters relevant sources
  3. Extracts performance claims
  4. Assembles a reviewable comparison

Hours later, you have an organized report ready for analysis—not scattered across browser tabs.

Architecture

Section titled “Architecture”

Kestrel uses a two-agent architecture:

Research Agent

Section titled “Research Agent”

Executes concrete micro-tasks:

  • Search → Retrieve → Filter → Extract → Narrow summary
  • Proposes specific follow-ups when evidence warrants it

Orchestrator

Section titled “Orchestrator”

Plans and coordinates the overall effort:

  • Schedules work across agents
  • Tracks progress and blockers
  • Pivots when stalled
  • Emits checkpoints you can accept or adjust

Orchestrator Profiles

Section titled “Orchestrator Profiles”
ProfileScope & BehaviorTypical Runtime
HummingbirdQuick breadth-first sweeps; targeted lookupsMinutes–~2h
KestrelMedium-horizon exploration with closely related branchesMulti-hour
AlbatrossLong-horizon, open-ended exploration with reviewsDay-scale+

The names are mnemonic—community-authored profiles with clear behaviors are welcome.

Tech Stack

Section titled “Tech Stack”
  • Backend: FastAPI
  • Frontend: React
  • Middleware: Redis
  • Model Runner: Ollama

More model engines and integrations are under development!

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Ollama - Recommended for Apple Silicon (GPU passthrough limitations)
  • Docker Desktop

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

After a few minutes of building, the application launches at http://localhost:5173/.

Alternative: Pre-built Images

Section titled “Alternative: Pre-built Images”

Images are built through GitHub Actions:

Usage

Section titled “Usage”

Using Kestrel is straightforward:

  1. Create a new task with a description
  2. Set a time-box for the research
  3. Monitor progress via the dashboard
  4. Review checkpoints and redirect if needed
  5. Export results when complete

The dashboard lets you track:

  • Searches and resulting sources
  • Checkpoints and reports
  • Agent progress and status

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Task Exploration

Section titled “Task Exploration”

Kestrel doesn’t just follow a linear path—it leverages gathered evidence to iterate on tasks, identifying and pursuing new branches as they emerge from the research.

Source Provenance

Section titled “Source Provenance”

Every search and its impact on findings is recorded, creating an auditable trail of how conclusions were reached.

Long-Running Support

Section titled “Long-Running Support”

Instead of a single final report, Kestrel surfaces checkpoints throughout the process, allowing for course correction and redirection.

Small LLM Friendly

Section titled “Small LLM Friendly”

Designed to run efficiently with models in the 1-7B parameter range via Ollama—no GPU cluster required.

Development Status

Section titled “Development Status”

Kestrel is actively developed with regular updates. Check the GitHub Issues for:

  • Top feature requests (add your 👍 votes)
  • Bug reports and known issues
  • Community discussions

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

All contributions are appreciated! Kestrel is meant to be a practical, community-focused project. Areas of contribution:

  • New orchestrator profiles for specific use cases
  • Additional model engine integrations
  • UI/UX improvements
  • Documentation and examples

See CONTRIBUTING.md for guidelines.

Why Kestrel Matters

Section titled “Why Kestrel Matters”

Most AI tools optimize for quick responses. Kestrel optimizes for deep, sustained research that happens alongside your core work. By running locally and respecting resource constraints, it makes AI-powered research assistance accessible without:

  • Expensive API subscriptions
  • Privacy concerns with cloud services
  • Dependency on internet connectivity

It’s research assistance that works on your terms, with your hardware, and for your timeline.

Quotio: Stop Juggling AI Accounts - A macOS Menu Bar App That Unifies Claude, Gemini, OpenAI, Qwen, and Antigravity

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Quotio: Stop Juggling AI Accounts

Section titled “Quotio: Stop Juggling AI Accounts”

Stop juggling AI accounts. Quotio is a beautiful native macOS menu bar app that unifies your Claude, Gemini, OpenAI, Qwen, and Antigravity subscriptions – with real-time quota tracking and smart auto-failover for AI coding tools like Claude Code, OpenCode, and Droid.

Introduction: The AI Account Management Problem

Section titled “Introduction: The AI Account Management Problem”

As developers, we increasingly rely on multiple AI coding assistants in our daily work. You might use Claude Code for intelligent code completion, GitHub Copilot for inline suggestions, Cursor for AI-powered IDE features, and various OpenAI-based tools for different tasks. Each service comes with its own:

  • Subscription and billing
  • API keys and authentication
  • Usage quotas and rate limits
  • Separate dashboard and management interface

This fragmentation creates constant overhead. You’re juggling multiple browser tabs, switching between different CLI configurations, and inevitably hitting rate limits on one service while another sits idle. Enter Quotio – a unified solution that brings all your AI subscriptions under one roof.

What is Quotio?

Section titled “What is Quotio?”

Quotio is a native macOS application that provides unified quota monitoring and request routing for multiple AI provider services. Created by developer Trong Nguyen (nguyenphutrong), Quotio serves two complementary purposes:

  1. Visual Dashboard – Track all your AI API usage limits in one beautiful interface
  2. Optional Local Proxy – Route requests across multiple provider accounts with intelligent load balancing and failover

Dual-Mode Architecture

Section titled “Dual-Mode Architecture”

Quotio offers two operation modes to suit different needs:

Quota-Only Mode

Section titled “Quota-Only Mode”

A lightweight mode perfect for users who simply want visibility into their AI usage:

  • Real-time quota tracking by reading authentication files from installed CLI tools
  • Support for Claude Code, Codex CLI, Gemini CLI, GitHub Copilot, Cursor, and Antigravity
  • macOS menu bar integration for at-a-glance quota status
  • System notifications for low quota warnings
  • No proxy server required – minimal resource footprint

Full Mode

Section titled “Full Mode”

All Quota-Only features plus powerful proxy capabilities:

  • Local proxy server for request routing and load balancing
  • OAuth-based provider authentication
  • Automatic failover between accounts when quotas are exhausted
  • API key management for secure proxy access
  • Comprehensive usage statistics and request logging
  • Automatic configuration of CLI agents to use the proxy

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Multi-Provider Support

Section titled “1. Multi-Provider Support”

Quotio unifies 10 AI providers in a single interface:

ProviderQuota-Only ModeFull Mode
Claude✅✅
Gemini✅✅
OpenAI✅✅
Qwen✅✅
Antigravity✅✅
GitHub Copilot✅✅
Cursor✅✅
Codex CLI✅✅

2. Real-Time Quota Tracking

Section titled “2. Real-Time Quota Tracking”

The menu bar integration provides at-a-glance quota status:

  • Provider symbol (1-2 letters) + lowest percentage across models
  • Example: "G:95% C:42% CP:88%" (Gemini 95%, Claude 42%, Copilot 88%)
  • Color-coded indicators: green (>50%), orange (20-50%), red (<20%)
  • Customizable display options – show/hide providers, change color modes

3. Smart Auto-Failover

Section titled “3. Smart Auto-Failover”

In Full Mode, Quotio acts as an intelligent proxy:

When one account hits its quota limit, Quotio automatically routes requests to another available account, ensuring uninterrupted workflow.

4. Menu Bar Integration

Section titled “4. Menu Bar Integration”

The persistent macOS menu bar presence keeps you informed without interrupting your workflow:

  • Always-visible quota status
  • Quick access to detailed dashboard
  • Low quota notifications
  • Language support: English and Vietnamese

Installation and Setup

Section titled “Installation and Setup”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • macOS 14.6 or later
  • Accounts with supported AI providers (Claude, Gemini, OpenAI, etc.)

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”
  1. Download Quotio from the GitHub Releases page
  2. Launch the app and complete the onboarding flow
  3. Choose your mode: Quota-Only (lightweight) or Full (with proxy)
  4. Connect your accounts via OAuth or manual authentication
  5. Configure your coding tools to use the Quotio proxy (Full Mode)

For AI coding tools, Quotio provides automatic configuration:

Use Cases and Best Practices

Section titled “Use Cases and Best Practices”

For Individual Developers

Section titled “For Individual Developers”

Scenario: You’re a developer using Claude Code for daily work, but you also have access to Gemini and OpenAI APIs for side projects.

Solution: Quotio lets you see all your quotas at a glance and automatically routes requests when one provider is exhausted.

For Teams

Section titled “For Teams”

Scenario: Your team has multiple AI subscriptions across different providers, and team members frequently hit rate limits during peak hours.

Solution: Configure Quotio with multiple accounts per provider for intelligent load distribution and automatic failover.

For Cost Optimization

Section titled “For Cost Optimization”

Scenario: You want to maximize usage of your AI subscriptions before upgrading to higher tiers.

Solution: Use Quotio’s detailed usage statistics to understand consumption patterns and make informed decisions about subscription upgrades.

Technical Architecture

Section titled “Technical Architecture”

Built with modern macOS development practices:

  • Framework: SwiftUI with AppKit integration
  • Architecture: MVVM with Actor Model for thread-safe services
  • Concurrency: Swift Concurrency (async/await, actors)
  • Localization: English and Vietnamese support
  • Auto-Updates: Sparkle framework for seamless updates

The project structure follows clean architecture principles:

Conclusion

Quotio solves a real pain point for developers who use multiple AI services. By providing unified quota monitoring, intelligent request routing, and seamless failover, it transforms the fragmented experience of managing multiple AI subscriptions into a cohesive, productive workflow.

Whether you’re an individual developer juggling personal AI subscriptions or part of a team with multiple provider accounts, Quotio offers the tools you need to maximize your AI productivity.

The wechat-article-writer skill for Claude Code automates this entire workflow, allowing content creators to produce professional articles in minutes rather than hours.

What is wechat-article-writer?

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Section titled “Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML”

When using Claude Code for software development, every session contains valuable insights — debugging approaches, architectural decisions, and problem-solving techniques. But these conversations are locked away in JSON files buried in ~/.claude/projects.

Simon Willison has released claude-code-transcripts, a Python CLI tool that converts these session files into beautiful, browsable HTML transcripts that can be shared with others.

What is claude-code-transcripts?

Section titled “What is claude-code-transcripts?”

claude-code-transcripts is a command-line tool that converts Claude Code session data (stored as JSON or JSONL files) into paginated, mobile-friendly HTML transcripts. It provides:

  • Better readability than the raw Claude Code interface
  • Shareable output that works with any static hosting or GitHub Gists
  • Multiple input sources: local sessions, web sessions via API, or direct JSON files
  • Clean, organized layout with pagination for long sessions

GitHub Repository: simonw/claude-code-transcripts Author: Simon Willison License: Apache 2.0 PyPI: claude-code-transcripts

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The tool can be installed using uv (recommended) or run directly without installation:

Four Main Commands

Section titled “Four Main Commands”

The tool provides four commands for different use cases:

1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions

Section titled “1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions”

Convert sessions stored locally in ~/.claude/projects:

2. web - Import from Claude API

Section titled “2. web - Import from Claude API”

Fetch sessions directly from the Claude web API:

On macOS, credentials are automatically retrieved from your keychain. On other platforms, use --token and --org-uuid.

3. json - Convert Specific Files

Section titled “3. json - Convert Specific Files”

Convert a JSON or JSONL session file directly:

4. all - Archive All Sessions

Section titled “4. all - Archive All Sessions”

Convert all local sessions into a browsable HTML archive:

This creates a directory structure with:

  • A master index listing all projects
  • Per-project pages listing sessions
  • Individual session transcripts

Output Options

Section titled “Output Options”

All commands support these useful options:

OptionDescription
-o, --output DIROutput directory (default: temp dir + open browser)
-a, --output-autoAuto-name subdirectory based on session ID
--repo OWNER/NAMEGitHub repo for commit links
--openOpen generated HTML in default browser
--gistUpload to GitHub Gist and return preview URL
--jsonInclude original session file in output

Publishing to GitHub Gist

Section titled “Publishing to GitHub Gist”

One of the most powerful features is the --gist option:

This requires the GitHub CLI to be installed and authenticated. The output includes:

Example Output

Section titled “Example Output”

The tool generates:

  • index.html - Timeline page with prompts and commits
  • page-001.html, page-002.html, etc. - Paginated transcript pages

See an example transcript created by Simon.

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”
  1. Documentation - Turn complex debugging sessions into reference documentation
  2. Knowledge Sharing - Share architectural decisions with your team
  3. Tutorials - Create step-by-step guides from real coding sessions
  4. Archiving - Build a searchable archive of your development work
  5. Blogging - Transform interesting sessions into blog posts

Technical Details

Section titled “Technical Details”
  • Input Sources: Local ~/.claude/projects, Claude Web API, or JSON/JSONL files
  • Output Format: Static HTML with CSS, no build step required
  • Dependencies: Python 3.8+, minimal dependencies
  • Platform Support: macOS, Linux, Windows

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
Featureclaude-code-transcriptsclaude-notes
GitHub Gist integration✅ Built-in❌ No
Web API support✅ Yes❌ Local only
Archive all sessions✅ Yes❌ Per-file only
Mobile-friendly✅ Yes✅ Yes
Pagination✅ Yes✅ Yes

Both tools serve similar purposes, but claude-code-transcripts offers more advanced features for sharing and publishing.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

claude-code-transcripts fills an important gap in the Claude Code ecosystem by making sessions shareable and readable outside the Claude Code interface. Whether you’re documenting your work, sharing with colleagues, or building a knowledge base, this tool transforms ephemeral AI conversations into permanent, valuable resources.

BMAD Method: How to Turn LLM System Prompts into a Reproducible AI Dev Team

Dec 27, 2025
Vibe Sparking

BMAD Method is an open-source AI-driven agile development methodology and toolkit based on the BMAD Core framework. It includes 19 professional AI Agents and 50+ Workflows covering the complete lifecycle from requirements analysis, planning, and architecture design to development and testing. It has garnered 23.6k stars on GitHub (as of December 2025). It packages system prompts, role definitions, and process instructions into structured assets, allowing you to orchestrate a team of AI experts working together like a real software development team, rather than copying and pasting fragmented prompts.

Why Do You Need a Systematic System Prompt Repository?

Section titled “Why Do You Need a Systematic System Prompt Repository?”

Most AI learners and developers encounter these pain points when using large language models:

  • Disorganized system prompts: You write a good system prompt in Claude today, modify it in ChatGPT tomorrow, and end up with prompts scattered across conversations and documents, unable to find the best version.
  • Unstable AI roles: Sometimes you want it to be a product manager, sometimes an architect, sometimes QA, but you have to re-explain each time with inconsistent results and unstable output quality.
  • Lack of closed-loop from requirements to code: Even if you’ve written many prompts, they’re mostly one-off: requirements documents have one style, architecture discussions another, development and testing yet another. These prompts lack strict artifact flow relationships, making it hard to form a replicable engineering process.
  • High collaboration costs: When you want to share your collection of prompts with colleagues, they can only copy from a long document or Notion page one by one—completely non-toolified.

If you’ve experienced similar issues, what BMAD Method does can be understood as:

Engineering, versioning, and portable AI system prompts + role division + process steps, transforming them into an AI team framework that can be repeatedly reused across various IDEs and AI tools.

What is BMAD Method Essentially?

Section titled “What is BMAD Method Essentially?”

The positioning of BMAD Method can be summarized in one sentence:

Breakthrough Method for Agile AI-Driven Development — A framework that enables AI to participate in development as an agile team.

Its core has three layers:

  • BMAD Core: A foundational framework designed for human + multi-agent collaboration, containing:

    • Agents (professional role personas) written in Markdown
    • Agent Teams composed of multiple agents
    • Workflows (strategic processes) defined in YAML
    • Templates with LLM instructions (PRD, architecture documents, Story files, etc.)

  • BMAD Method: Built on top of BMAD Core, focusing on software development workflows, breaking down the entire chain from analysis → planning → solution → implementation into multiple stages and artifacts, completed by different agents in relay.

  • BMAD Builder / Creative Intelligence Suite:

    • BMAD Builder: Allows you to design your own professional agents and modules on the same framework (e.g., legal, finance, education fields).
    • Creative Intelligence Suite: Provides creative thinking and brainstorming workflows to assist product innovation and narrative design.

In other words, BMAD Method is not just a simple prompt collection. It structures system prompts by:

  • Roles (who does it)
  • Stages (when to do it)
  • Artifacts (what to produce)
  • Tools (where to use them)

All structured into an engineering methodology and code repository that can be ported to your project.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. 19 Professional AI Roles to Build a Virtual Development Team

Section titled “1. 19 Professional AI Roles to Build a Virtual Development Team”

BMAD includes a small virtual company:

  • Analyst
  • Product Manager
  • Architect
  • Scrum Master
  • Product Owner
  • Developer
  • QA Engineer
  • UX Designer, Game Designer, Tech Writer, etc.

Each role has:

  • Clear responsibilities
  • Corresponding commands (such as @analyst, @pm, @dev)
  • Corresponding document types to produce (PRD, architecture specs, Story files, QA reports)

These definitions are written in Markdown + system prompts—you don’t need to reinvent how to make a model play a qualified product manager—just call the existing persona directly.

2. 50+ Workflows Covering the Complete Development Lifecycle

Section titled “2. 50+ Workflows Covering the Complete Development Lifecycle”

BMAD Method breaks down the entire software delivery process into 4 stages:

  1. Analysis: Requirements discovery, market research, solution comparison
  2. Planning: PRD, technical specs, game design documents, etc.
  3. Solutioning: System architecture, data flow, API design, UX sketches
  4. Implementation: Story-driven development, code implementation, testing verification

For each stage, the framework provides multiple workflows defined in YAML form with process and call order. For example:

  • Use Analyst to generate Project Brief
  • Use PM to generate PRD
  • Use Architect to generate Architecture document
  • Use PO for document sharding
  • Use SM to generate Story files
  • Use Developer/QA for implementation and verification

This is essentially an executable system prompt process, not a bunch of scattered prompt examples.

3. Scale-Adaptive Intelligence: Three Intelligence Tracks

Section titled “3. Scale-Adaptive Intelligence: Three Intelligence Tracks”

BMAD provides three intelligence tracks:

  • Quick Flow: Suitable for bug fixes and small requirements, generating lightweight technical specs, ready to code in minutes.
  • BMad Method Standard Track: For new features, new products, or medium-sized platforms, from PRD to architecture to UX.
  • Enterprise Track: For projects with high compliance, governance requirements, providing more complete documentation, quality gates, and processes.

In practice, you can run *workflow-init to let BMAD automatically recommend the appropriate track based on goals and context.

4. Story / Sharding System: Documents as First-Class Engineering Citizens

Section titled “4. Story / Sharding System: Documents as First-Class Engineering Citizens”

BMAD emphasizes document sharding and Story file systems:

  • Break large PRDs into multiple Epic files
  • Generate Story files with complete context from Epics (e.g., 1.1.user-registration.story.md)
  • Story files include:
    • Architecture background
    • Implementation details
    • Acceptance criteria
    • Related constraints

Finally, Developer and QA work around Story files—creating a strict mapping between system prompts + documents + code, facilitating version control, auditing, and rollback.

5. Modular Architecture Based on BMAD Core

Section titled “5. Modular Architecture Based on BMAD Core”

At the framework level, BMAD explicitly divides itself into several modules:

  • Agents: Markdown persona definitions (essentially structured system prompts)
  • Agent Teams: Reusable team combinations
  • Workflows: YAML process definitions
  • Templates: Document templates with embedded LLM instructions
  • Expansion Packs: Extensions for specific fields (creative, business, education, health, etc.)

This means: if you’re working on organizing LLM system prompts, you can directly follow this directory structure and abstraction approach, building your prompt repository on the same architecture.

6. IDE & Toolchain Integration

Section titled “6. IDE & Toolchain Integration”

BMAD is not a framework that only works in a specific web page—it has been verified and integrated in many development tools:

  • Supports Cursor, Windsurf, and other AI IDEs via @agent syntax
  • Compatible with VS Code extensions like Cline, RooCode, Augment, Aider
  • Provides command-line tools based on Node.js 20+ (npx bmad-method)
  • Can run complete workflows in browser Web UI

For developers accustomed to asking AI while writing in IDEs, this is much more comfortable than copying and pasting prompts in browser tabs.

7. Token Savings and Update Safety

Section titled “7. Token Savings and Update Safety”

In large projects, you often encounter contexts that are too long and token limits. BMAD’s approach is:

  • Use the document sharding mechanism to feed each agent only the part of the context it needs
  • Official claims up to ~90% token savings (for large projects)

At the same time, the framework is designed with update safety in mind:

  • Your custom configuration is by default placed in directories that won’t be overwritten
  • When upgrading BMAD versions, your personalized agent and workflow settings are preserved

8. Web Bundles and Multi-Model Support

Section titled “8. Web Bundles and Multi-Model Support”

BMAD provides so-called Web Bundles, allowing you to reuse the same set of agent and process definitions on:

  • ChatGPT
  • Claude Projects
  • Gemini Gems

This is very friendly for students researching different LLM performance differences—you can run the same BMAD workflow on different models and compare output quality horizontally.

Technical Architecture: From System Prompts to Executable Processes

Section titled “Technical Architecture: From System Prompts to Executable Processes”

To more intuitively understand BMAD Method’s technical structure, we can summarize each core component in the following table:

ComponentLogical Location / FormContent CarriedRole in System Prompt Engineering
Agentsbmad-core/agents/ (Markdown)Professional role personas, behavior guidelines, communication stylesBreaking long system prompts into role definitions
Agent Teamsbmad-core/agent-teams/Combination configurations of multiple agentsDescribing what an AI team looks like
Workflowsbmad-core/workflows/ (YAML)Multi-stage processes, dependencies, command callsStringing multiple roles and prompts into complete processes
Templatesbmad-core/templates/ (Markdown)PRD, architecture docs, Story templates + LLM instructionsMaking LLMs output artifacts in unified format
Expansion PacksExtension directories / independent modulesDomain-specific agents / workflowsCopying this methodology to other industries

If you’re organizing your own LLM system prompt repository, it’s well worth referencing BMAD’s layered approach: upgrading prompt text into combinations of roles + processes + templates, rather than isolated strings.

From Installation to Running Your First Workflow

Section titled “From Installation to Running Your First Workflow”

Although BMAD looks heavy, it’s actually quite straightforward to get started.

BMAD will recommend based on your project goals:

  • Quick Flow
  • Standard BMAD Method
  • Enterprise track

And provide suggested next steps.

A System Prompt Closed-Loop Example from Requirements to Launch

Section titled “A System Prompt Closed-Loop Example from Requirements to Launch”

Based on the official e-commerce example, BMAD’s complete process is roughly as follows:

  1. Analyst: Project Vision and Market Analysis

    • Command example: @analyst Create project brief for modern e-commerce platform
    • Output: project-brief.md

  2. Product Manager: Generate PRD

    • Functional Requirements (FR)
    • Non-Functional Requirements (NFR)
    • Epic list and user story hierarchy
    • Use Analyst’s Brief as input
    • Output: PRD.md

  3. Architect: System Architecture Design

    • Output: architecture.md, including tech stack, system components, data flows, and API specifications.

  4. Product Owner: Document Sharding

    • Break PRD + architecture docs into focused Epic files, such as:
      • epic-1-user-auth.md
      • epic-2-products.md

  5. Scrum Master: Generate Story Files

    • Generate Story files for a specific Epic, such as:
      • 1.1.user-registration.story.md
    • Story includes context, implementation details, acceptance criteria, etc.

  6. Developer: Code Implementation

    • Implement code around Story files (Controllers, components, database migrations, etc.) and generate test cases.

  7. QA: Quality Verification and Tracking

    • Produce a series of QA documents including test strategy, tracking matrix, quality gate reports.

In this entire process, you can see:

  • Each stage corresponds to one or more agents
  • Each agent is backed by a highly structured system prompt
  • Artifacts (documents & code) form strict tracking chains through filenames and directory structures

This is the concrete embodiment of treating system prompts as engineering assets.

Who is BMAD Suitable For?

Section titled “Who is BMAD Suitable For?”

Combined with official documentation and technical articles, BMAD Method is well-suited for the following users and scenarios:

1. AI Learners Wanting to Systematically Organize LLM System Prompts

Section titled “1. AI Learners Wanting to Systematically Organize LLM System Prompts”

You’ve already accumulated many prompts: writing requirements, reviewing code, generating tests, but now they’re scattered across chat history, documents, and your brain.

BMAD provides you with a template for:

  • How to break down roles
  • How to break down stages
  • How to design artifact formats

You can gradually migrate and upgrade your prompt repository within this structure.

2. Small Teams / Startups: Want AI to Truly Participate in the Delivery Loop

Section titled “2. Small Teams / Startups: Want AI to Truly Participate in the Delivery Loop”

For a team of two or three people, hiring a few AI employees is often more realistic than hiring another person. BMAD can help you:

  • Use Analyst/PM/Architect to help plan your product
  • Use Developer/QA to help quickly implement and verify
  • Through documents and Story files, let team members take over AI-produced work outcomes at any time

Especially in scenarios requiring frequent iteration like SaaS, internal tools, e-commerce platforms, this framework from Spec to Code has significant advantages.

3. Large Companies / Enterprise Teams: Scenarios Requiring Governance, Auditing, and Compliance

Section titled “3. Large Companies / Enterprise Teams: Scenarios Requiring Governance, Auditing, and Compliance”

In more serious enterprise environments, casually writing prompts in chat boxes is hard to pass compliance and auditing. BMAD’s advantages include:

  • All instructions are reflected through files and command lines
  • All documents and code are versioned in Git
  • Workflows and responsibility divisions are traceable

This makes system prompts no longer invisible rules, but auditable, reproducible artifacts.

BMAD vs Other Solutions

Section titled “BMAD vs Other Solutions”

From the perspective of system prompt engineering / prompt repositories, BMAD is not the only solution.

Project / FrameworkCore PositioningPrompt / System Description FormIncludes Complete Development WorkflowBest Scenarios
BMAD MethodAI-driven agile development framework + agent team collaborationAgents (Markdown persona), Workflows (YAML), Templates (document templates)✅ Full chain from requirements to QASoftware and product development, teams wanting to engineer system prompts
PromptSourcePrompt IDE and repository for NLP datasets2000+ prompts for ~170 datasets, supporting template language and visual debugging❌ More biased toward dataset tasksAcademic research, benchmarking, building NLP task prompt sets
BMAD Prompt MCPBMAD-First prompt engineering serverRaw prompt → BMAD structured prompt via MCP interface🔁 Focuses on single-task prompt structuringEngineers wanting to unify prompt specifications in tools
Prompt CommonsPrompt governance and versioning in city governance scenariosVersioned prompt repository concept with governance metadata and authorization info❌ More research and concept levelResearch and government projects needing prompt management from strategy/governance perspective

Simply put:

  • PromptSource is more biased toward development tools for different NLP datasets with different prompts
  • BMAD Prompt MCP is a supplement that makes BMAD method into a prompt engineering service
  • Prompt Commons is more like a future vision and framework for city/enterprise-level prompt governance

And BMAD Method’s uniqueness lies in:

  • It designs system prompts + roles + workflows + documents as a whole
  • Provides complete implementation paths from command line to IDE, from Web UI to Git repository
  • Has formed a large open-source ecosystem and user group on GitHub (23.6k stars, 3.4k forks)

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

If we compress this article into one sentence:

BMAD Method demonstrates a typical path to system prompt engineering: abstract roles with Agents, abstract processes with Workflows, abstract outputs with Templates, and abstract the entire collaboration history with Git.

For those running tech blogs, teaching AI, or doing daily projects, what you can learn from this repository is not just which prompt works better, but:

  • How to design structured personas for different roles
  • How to create strict mapping between prompts, documents, and code
  • How to manage the entire AI collaboration process through file structure and version control

Even if you don’t directly use all of BMAD Method’s features, you can absolutely treat it as a system prompt engineering practice textbook, following its directory structure and workflow approach to build your own LLM system prompt repository.

Section titled “Reference Links”

  • BMAD Official Docs: https://bmad-method.org

RAG-Anything: All-in-One Multimodal RAG Framework

Dec 27, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Explore HKUDS/RAG-Anything, a comprehensive multimodal document processing RAG system that handles text, images, tables, and equations in a unified framework built on LightRAG.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Modern documents increasingly contain diverse multimodal content—text, images, tables, equations, charts, and multimedia—that traditional text-focused RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) systems cannot effectively process. RAG-Anything by HKUDS addresses this challenge as a comprehensive All-in-One Multimodal Document Processing RAG system built on LightRAG.

RAG-Anything eliminates the need for multiple specialized tools by providing seamless processing and querying across all content modalities within a single integrated framework. This consolidated approach makes it particularly valuable for academic research, technical documentation, financial reports, and enterprise knowledge management.

Paper: RAG-Anything: All-in-One RAG Framework (arXiv:2510.12323)

Multimodal Knowledge GraphAutomatic entity extraction and cross-modal relationship discovery
Adaptive Processing ModesMinerU-based parsing or direct multimodal content injection

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Match Parser to Content Type: Use MinerU for complex layouts, Docling for Office documents
  2. Enable Only Needed Features: Reduce overhead by selectively enabling image/table/equation processing
  3. Use Appropriate Query Modes: local for context-specific, global for pattern discovery, hybrid for balanced results
  4. Batch Process Similar Documents: Use process_folder_complete for efficiency
  5. Pre-parse When Possible: Use insert_content_list for cached/external parsing results

Antigravity Manager: The Professional AI Account Manager & Switcher

Dec 26, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Antigravity Manager: The Professional AI Account Manager & Switcher

Section titled “Antigravity Manager: The Professional AI Account Manager & Switcher”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, developers and enthusiasts often find themselves juggling multiple accounts across different services like Google Gemini and Anthropic Claude. Antigravity Manager is a professional desktop application designed to solve this problem by acting as a “Local AI Relay Station.”

What is Antigravity Manager?

Section titled “What is Antigravity Manager?”

Antigravity Manager is a powerful tool built with Tauri v2, Rust, and React that allows you to manage multiple AI accounts in one place. It transforms web-based AI sessions into standardized, OpenAI-compatible API interfaces, enabling you to use your favorite clients (like NextChat, Claude Code, or custom scripts) with various AI providers seamlessly.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
  • Unified Account Dashboard: Monitor global quotas, token status, and usage in real-time.
  • One-Click Switching: Seamlessly switch between different accounts and models.
  • Protocol Conversion: Converts web sessions into standard API formats.
  • Model Router: Create custom routing rules to direct traffic to specific models or accounts.
  • Multimodal Support: Full support for vision tasks and high-quality image generation (e.g., Imagen 3).
  • MCP Compatibility: Enhanced compatibility with the Model Context Protocol, ensuring smooth operation with tools like Claude Code.

Prerequisites & Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites & Installation”

Antigravity Manager supports macOS, Windows, and Linux.

macOS Installation (Recommended)

Section titled “macOS Installation (Recommended)”

The easiest way to install on macOS is via Homebrew:

Manual Installation

Section titled “Manual Installation”

You can also download the latest binaries from the GitHub Releases page.

Note for macOS Users: If you install manually, you might need to bypass the quarantine flag:

Recommended Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios”

1. Developer Workflow Optimization

Section titled “1. Developer Workflow Optimization”

If you use tools like Claude Code or Cursor, you can point them to Antigravity Manager’s local proxy (default http://127.0.0.1:8045). This allows you to switch the underlying model or account without changing configuration files in your development environment.

2. Unified Chat Experience

Section titled “2. Unified Chat Experience”

Connect a chat client like NextChat or Chatbox to the local relay. You can then chat with Gemini, Claude, or other supported models from a single interface, leveraging the “Model Router” to pick the best model for the task.

Configuration & Usage

Section titled “Configuration & Usage”
  1. Add Accounts: Launch the app and go to the “Accounts” tab. Log in to your AI providers (e.g., Google, Anthropic) to authorize the application.
  2. Start Proxy: Navigate to the “API Proxy” tab and start the service.
  3. Connect Clients: Use the proxy URL (http://127.0.0.1:8045/v1/chat/completions) and a generic API key (e.g., sk-antigravity) in your client applications.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Antigravity Manager simplifies the chaos of managing multiple AI subscriptions and API keys. By providing a unified, local interface, it empowers developers to focus on building and creating, rather than managing access.

Claude Code Board: Use Claude Code on Kanban WebUI

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code Board is a web-based Kanban-style management interface designed specifically for the Claude Code CLI. If you are a power user of Claude Code, you might find yourself juggling multiple terminal windows to handle different tasks concurrently. Claude Code Board solves this by providing a unified, visual interface to manage these sessions.

It aims to enhance the developer experience by allowing concurrent management of multiple AI coding sessions with real-time status tracking (idle, processing, completed, error).

Features

Section titled “Features”

Multi-Session Management

Section titled “Multi-Session Management”

Run multiple Claude Code instances simultaneously. The Kanban board allows you to see the status of each session at a glance—whether it’s idle, processing, or completed.

Advanced AI Workflows

Section titled “Advanced AI Workflows”
  • Agent Integration: Load custom Claude agents directly from your ~/.claude/agents/ directory.
  • Workflow Stages: Utilize pre-configured stages like Code Review, Bug Fixing, and Feature Development to structure your work.
  • Smart Prompting: Automatically inject agent instructions and custom templates to streamline your interaction with the AI.

Project Organization

Section titled “Project Organization”

Group your sessions under “Work Items,” tag them by project or topic, and automatically manage workspace paths. This keeps your work organized conceptually, not just by terminal ID.

Enhanced UI/UX

Section titled “Enhanced UI/UX”
  • WebSocket-powered chat: Real-time updates and interaction.
  • Notifications: Windows Toast notifications alert you when a task is completed.
  • Message Filtering: Filter out “thinking” blocks or tool use logs to focus on the conversation and results.
  • Session Recovery: Resume previous conversations with full context preservation.

Section titled “Concurrent Development”

Q: Can I use GLM Coding Plan alongside other Claude Code configurations?

A: Yes, you can switch between different API providers by changing environment variables or creating multiple profiles in your settings file.

Q: Is my code data sent to Zhipu AI servers?

Section titled “Q: Is my code data sent to Zhipu AI servers?”

A: Yes, similar to how Claude Code sends data to Anthropic. Review Zhipu AI’s data privacy policy for details on data handling and retention.

Q: Can I use GLM Coding Plan in Cursor or other IDEs?

Section titled “Q: Can I use GLM Coding Plan in Cursor or other IDEs?”

A: GLM Coding Plan is primarily designed for terminal-based Claude Code. However, you can configure similar API settings in Cursor if it supports custom endpoints.

Q: What’s the difference between GLM-4.7 and GLM-4.5-Air?

Section titled “Q: What’s the difference between GLM-4.7 and GLM-4.5-Air?”

A: GLM-4.7 is Zhipu’s most capable model for complex reasoning tasks, while GLM-4.5-Air is optimized for speed and cost efficiency on simpler tasks.

Q: How do I check which model is currently active?

Section titled “Q: How do I check which model is currently active?”

A: Run /status command in Claude Code to see the current model and configuration.

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • Zhipu AI GLM Coding Plan Documentation
  • Claude Code Official Documentation
  • Zhipu AI Developer Console
  • GLM Model Documentation

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

GLM Coding Plan brings the power of Zhipu AI’s GLM models to Claude Code, offering a compelling alternative for developers who prefer China-hosted models or need better Chinese language understanding. With proper configuration and model selection, you can achieve productivity gains while maintaining data locality.

The integration is straightforward, the documentation is comprehensive, and the official support from Zhipu AI ensures a smooth experience. Whether you’re building new features or debugging existing code, GLM Coding Plan has you covered.

Happy coding with GLM!

Superpowers: Transform Claude Code Into a Disciplined Development Workflow Engine

Dec 26, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

What if Claude Code could enforce engineering discipline instead of just writing code? That’s exactly what obra/superpowers delivers—a complete software development workflow system built on composable “skills” that automatically activate to guide your development process.

With over 11,800 stars and 960 forks on GitHub, Superpowers has become the go-to framework for developers who want their AI coding assistant to follow systematic engineering practices rather than ad-hoc code generation.

The Core Philosophy: Engineering Discipline Over Quick Fixes

Section titled “The Core Philosophy: Engineering Discipline Over Quick Fixes”

Superpowers enforces four fundamental principles:

PrincipleDescription
Test-Driven DevelopmentWrite tests first, always. Code written before tests may be deleted
Systematic over Ad-hocFollow defined processes rather than guessing
Complexity ReductionSimplicity as the primary goal (YAGNI, DRY)
Evidence over ClaimsVerify fixes work before declaring success

This isn’t about adding more features—it’s about fundamentally changing how AI agents approach software development.

How Superpowers Works: The Five-Phase Workflow

Section titled “How Superpowers Works: The Five-Phase Workflow”

When you start a project with Superpowers enabled, Claude Code follows a structured workflow:

Phase 1: Design First (Brainstorming)

Section titled “Phase 1: Design First (Brainstorming)”

Instead of immediately writing code, the agent “steps back and asks what you’re really trying to do.” Through Socratic dialogue, it:

  • Explores your requirements through questions
  • Considers alternatives and edge cases
  • Presents design in digestible chunks for approval
  • Saves a specification document

Phase 2: Planning

Section titled “Phase 2: Planning”

After design approval, it creates an implementation plan that’s “clear enough for an enthusiastic junior engineer” to follow:

  • Breaks work into 2-5 minute tasks
  • Specifies exact file paths and code locations
  • Includes verification steps for each task
  • Emphasizes TDD, YAGNI, and DRY principles

Phase 3: Isolated Development (Git Worktrees)

Section titled “Phase 3: Isolated Development (Git Worktrees)”

The system creates isolated workspaces:

Phase 4: Subagent Execution

Section titled “Phase 4: Subagent Execution”

Here’s where the magic happens—autonomous execution with quality gates:

  • Fresh subagents handle individual tasks
  • Two-stage review: specification compliance, then code quality
  • The docs note: “It’s not uncommon for Claude to work autonomously for a couple hours at a time”

Phase 5: Completion

Section titled “Phase 5: Completion”
  • Verifies all tests pass
  • Offers merge or PR options
  • Cleans up worktrees
  • Presents summary with code review prompt

Q: How do I skip a workflow step? A: You can override, but it’s not recommended. The system is designed as a complete workflow.

Q: Does it work with non-TypeScript projects? A: Yes, the skills are language-agnostic. The principles apply to any codebase.

Alma: One Elegant Desktop App to Rule All Your AI Providers

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

The AI Provider Juggling Problem

Section titled “The AI Provider Juggling Problem”

If you’re like most AI power users, your workflow probably looks something like this:

  • ChatGPT tab for quick conversations
  • Claude tab for coding and analysis
  • Gemini tab for Google integration tasks
  • DeepSeek tab when you need cost-effective alternatives
  • A growing collection of API keys scattered across different tools

Sound familiar? You’re not alone. Managing multiple AI providers has become the new “too many browser tabs” problem.

Enter Alma — an elegant desktop solution that brings order to this chaos.

What is Alma?

Section titled “What is Alma?”

Alma is a beautifully designed macOS desktop application that serves as your unified command center for AI. Instead of switching between web interfaces, you access all your AI providers through one clean, intuitive interface.

Think of it as the universal remote for AI — one interface, multiple brains.

Who Built This?

Section titled “Who Built This?”

Alma comes from yetone, the same developer behind OpenAI Translator — a wildly popular project with 23.1k+ GitHub stars. That project evolved from a Chrome extension into a multi-platform desktop app, demonstrating yetone’s ability to build polished, production-ready tools.

This pedigree matters. Alma isn’t a weekend project — it’s built by someone with proven experience delivering AI-powered desktop applications that people actually use daily.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

Unified Chat Interface

Section titled “Unified Chat Interface”

A clean, intuitive chat interface that brings all your AI conversations together:

  • Markdown rendering for beautifully formatted responses
  • Code highlighting with syntax awareness
  • Real-time streaming responses as they’re generated
  • Dark/light theme toggle with smooth View Transitions API animations

Intelligent Memory System

Section titled “Intelligent Memory System”

Alma remembers context across conversations:

  • User preferences persist between sessions
  • Conversation context carries forward
  • Dedicated memory management panel for organization
  • View, organize, and prune memories as needed

Web Search Integration

Section titled “Web Search Integration”

Built-in capability to access real-time information:

  • AI can retrieve live web data when answering
  • No need to manually paste URLs or context
  • Current, accurate answers powered by actual web data

Advanced Tool Use

Why Alma Matters

Different models excel at different tasks. Claude might be your go-to for code, while GPT-4 shines at creative writing. Alma lets you switch contexts without switching apps.

Alma represents a shift from AI as scattered web services to AI as unified desktop infrastructure.

For users who regularly switch between multiple AI providers, this consolidation isn’t just convenient — it’s a workflow transformation. One app, multiple models, persistent memory, and an interface designed for daily use.

If you’re tired of juggling browser tabs and want a more sophisticated approach to AI provider management, Alma deserves a spot on your dock.

AntVis Infographic: Bring Words to Life with AI-Powered Visualization

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling

Section titled “The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling”

Creating professional infographics has always been a time-consuming process. Designers spend hours in tools like Figma, Illustrator, or Canva, manually arranging elements, adjusting colors, and ensuring visual consistency.

For developers and data scientists, the gap between raw data and compelling visual narratives feels even wider. You have the information — but turning it into something shareable and engaging requires skills that extend beyond code.

What if you could generate beautiful infographics with just text and data?

Enter AntV Infographic — Ant Group’s open-source, declarative infographic visualization engine that makes professional visual content creation accessible to everyone.

What is AntV Infographic?

Section titled “What is AntV Infographic?”

AntV Infographic is a next-generation declarative infographic visualization engine from the AntV team (part of Ant Group). With a carefully designed infographic syntax, it can quickly and flexibly render high-quality infographics, making information presentation more efficient and data storytelling simpler.

The framework is built with AI-native workflows in mind — its syntax is optimized for large language model generation, and it supports real-time streaming rendering.

Key metrics:

  • 200+ built-in templates for immediate use
  • SVG output for pixel-perfect quality at any size
  • MIT licensed and fully open source

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

AI-Friendly Design

Section titled “AI-Friendly Design”

The configuration and syntax are specifically tuned for AI generation:

  • Concise prompts that LLMs can understand and produce
  • Fault-tolerant parsing that handles partial or imperfect output
  • Streaming support for real-time progressive rendering

Ready-to-Use Components

Section titled “Ready-to-Use Components”

With ~200 built-in templates, data-item components, and layouts, you can build professional infographics in minutes:

Component TypeExamples
ListsHorizontal arrows, vertical timelines, comparison grids
ChartsPie, bar, line, radar integrated with narrative
DiagramsProcess flows, org charts, mind maps
Data ItemsStatistics, KPI cards, progress indicators

Theme System

Section titled “Theme System”

Multiple preset themes with deep customization options:

  • Hand-drawn style for informal, approachable content
  • Gradient themes for modern, dynamic presentations
  • Pattern-based themes for visual texture
  • Corporate presets for professional reports

Built-in Editor

Section titled “Built-in Editor”

AI-generated results can be edited further with the included WYSIWYG editor — no separate design tool required.

High-Quality SVG Output

Section titled “High-Quality SVG Output”

Renders with SVG by default to ensure:

  • Visual fidelity at any zoom level
  • Easy editing in vector tools
  • Small file sizes compared to raster images
  • Accessibility through structured markup

Section titled “The Infographic Syntax”

This simple syntax produces a professional horizontal arrow flow diagram with labeled steps — no design skills required.

Section titled “Real-Time Dashboards”

  • Update infographics as data changes
  • Stream AI analysis results directly to visuals
  • Build interactive data exploration tools

Create engaging learning materials:

  4. Export as SVG or other formats

For developers building AI applications, the prompt.md file provides optimized system prompts for LLM integration.

About AntV

Section titled “About AntV”

AntV was initiated by Ant Group and open-sourced starting in 2017, reimagining data visualization by embedding the theory of graphical grammar into JavaScript.

The AntV ecosystem includes:

  • G2 — A grammar of graphics for statistical charts
  • G6 — Graph visualization engine
  • L7 — Geospatial visualization
  • S2 — Spreadsheet-like visualization
  • Infographic — AI-native infographic generation

Beyond Technical Skills: What Really Matters for AI Software Engineers in 2025

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

When we talk about AI Software Engineers, most people immediately think of deep learning frameworks, Python proficiency, or years of experience with machine learning models. However, after analyzing real job postings and industry trends, I’ve discovered something profound: the qualities that truly differentiate successful AI engineers aren’t purely technical—they’re fundamentally human.

Let me share a recent job posting that crystallizes this insight perfectly.

The Job That Reveals Everything

Section titled “The Job That Reveals Everything”

Here’s a real AI Software Engineer position that caught my attention:

Job Responsibilities

Section titled “Job Responsibilities”

Responsible for R&D of AI products and services, designing and developing systems around business scenarios, providing solutions that meet business needs, and delivering reliable, stable, and scalable business systems quickly, cost-effectively, and continuously.

Basic Requirements

Section titled “Basic Requirements”
  • Bachelor’s degree or above in Computer Science, Communications, or related fields
  • Proficiency in at least one programming language: Java, Python, Go, TypeScript, etc.
  • Hands-on experience in AI-driven autonomous development products and services, able to effectively integrate AI capabilities into actual workflows
  • Good engineering practices, with fundamental pursuit of code quality, system stability, and maintainability

But Here’s What’s Really Important — The Soft Skill Requirements

Section titled “But Here’s What’s Really Important — The Soft Skill Requirements”
  1. Strong Sense of Responsibility: Take ownership of delivery results, continuously follow up on issues until closed
  2. Curiosity and Learning Ability: Stay sensitive to new technologies and tools, willing to proactively explore and quickly get up to speed
  3. Practical Execution Ability: Can quickly transform ideas into runnable, verifiable systems or features
  4. Planning Ability: Can reasonably decompose work tasks, autonomously evolve plans, and manage time arrangements
  5. Communication and Sharing Awareness: Willing to exchange technical solutions and experiences, possess cross-role collaboration capabilities

Why Soft Skills Outweigh Hard Skills in the AI Era

Section titled “Why Soft Skills Outweigh Hard Skills in the AI Era”

The Paradox of AI Development

Section titled “The Paradox of AI Development”

Here’s the irony: as AI becomes more capable of writing code, the value of pure coding skills diminishes. What AI cannot replicate are the uniquely human qualities:

  • Judgment — knowing when to apply AI and when human insight is needed
  • Responsibility — taking ownership of outcomes, not just outputs
  • Curiosity — asking “why” and “what if” rather than just “how”

Industry Data Supports This Shift

Section titled “Industry Data Supports This Shift”

According to IEEE Spectrum’s 2025 AI Jobs report, as tools like GitHub Copilot become adopted, the skill mix is shifting toward “uniquely human skills, like ethical reasoning or leadership.”

DataCamp’s analysis highlights that AI engineers need strong communication skills to “effectively communicate complex AI concepts to non-technical stakeholders.” This isn’t optional—it’s essential.

The Six Essential Qualities Decoded

Section titled “The Six Essential Qualities Decoded”

1. Strong Sense of Responsibility (责任心强)

Section titled “1. Strong Sense of Responsibility (责任心强)”

What it means: You don’t just write code—you own the outcome. When something breaks at 2 AM, you’re already investigating, not waiting for someone to assign you the ticket.

In practice:

  • Following issues through complete lifecycle, not just “throwing code over the wall”
  • Proactively monitoring systems you’ve built
  • Taking accountability for both successes and failures

Why AI can’t replace this: AI can generate code, but it cannot feel the weight of a production incident or the satisfaction of delivering real value to users.

2. Curiosity and Learning Ability (好奇心与学习能力)

Section titled “2. Curiosity and Learning Ability (好奇心与学习能力)”

What it means: The AI field moves at breakneck speed. What was state-of-the-art six months ago is now baseline. You must be intrinsically motivated to learn, not because your manager assigns a training course.

In practice:

  • Experimenting with new tools (Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot) on weekends
  • Reading research papers, not just documentation
  • Asking “why does this work?” not just “how do I use it?”

The compound effect: Anthropic’s best practices emphasize that working with AI agents is a skill that develops over time. The curiosity to iterate and improve separates novices from experts.

3. Practical Execution Ability (实践与执行能力)

Section titled “3. Practical Execution Ability (实践与执行能力)”

What it means: Ideas are worthless without execution. Can you transform a concept into a working prototype in days, not months?

In practice:

  • Building MVPs to validate hypotheses quickly
  • Knowing when “good enough” is actually good enough
  • Shipping iteratively rather than waiting for perfection

The AI amplification: With tools like AI coding assistants, execution speed has become a superpower. According to JetBrains’ guidelines, developers who can effectively guide AI agents ship 10x faster than those who code everything manually.

4. Planning Ability (规划能力)

Section titled “4. Planning Ability (规划能力)”

What it means: Breaking down complex problems into manageable chunks, sequencing work effectively, and managing time realistically.

In practice:

  • Decomposing a feature into specific, testable tasks
  • Knowing dependencies and critical paths
  • Estimating realistically (not optimistically)

Why this matters with AI: Medium’s guide on agent workflows emphasizes using “Plan–Act–Reflect” workflows. The clearer your structure, the better your AI agent performs.

5. Communication and Sharing Awareness (沟通与分享意识)

Section titled “5. Communication and Sharing Awareness (沟通与分享意识)”

What it means: Technical excellence in isolation is worthless. Can you explain your decisions to non-technical stakeholders? Can you mentor junior developers? Can you write documentation that others actually want to read?

In practice:

  • Writing clear, concise documentation
  • Participating in code reviews constructively
  • Sharing learnings in team meetings or blog posts

The multiplier effect: A developer who can communicate effectively multiplies their impact across the entire organization. Knowledge shared is knowledge amplified.

6. The Hidden Sixth Quality: Adaptability

Section titled “6. The Hidden Sixth Quality: Adaptability”

Though not explicitly listed, there’s an implicit requirement threading through all the others: adaptability. The willingness to change tools, approaches, and even mental models as the AI landscape evolves.

Comparative Analysis: Traditional vs. AI-Era Engineer

Section titled “Comparative Analysis: Traditional vs. AI-Era Engineer”
DimensionTraditional Software EngineerAI-Era Software Engineer
Primary ToolIDE + Search EngineIDE + AI Assistant + Agent
Code SourceMostly self-writtenHybrid (human-AI collaboration)
DebuggingRead stack tracesPrompt AI to analyze
Learning CurveMaster one stack deeplyContinuously adapt to new tools
Key DifferentiatorTechnical depthJudgment + Communication + Execution
Career GrowthSenior IC or ManagerAgent Orchestrator + Technical Lead

Practical Recommendations

Section titled “Practical Recommendations”

For Job Seekers

Section titled “For Job Seekers”
  1. Build a Portfolio of AI-Assisted Projects: Show that you can effectively leverage AI tools, not just code from scratch
  2. Document Your Decision-Making Process: Blog about why you chose certain approaches, not just what you built
  3. Demonstrate Cross-Functional Collaboration: Highlight projects where you worked with designers, PMs, and business stakeholders
  4. Show Continuous Learning: Your GitHub should have recent experiments, not just code from years ago

For Hiring Managers

Section titled “For Hiring Managers”
  1. Redesign Interview Questions: Ask candidates how they’d approach problems with AI assistance, not just algorithmic puzzles
  2. Evaluate Soft Skills Explicitly: Structured behavioral interviews for responsibility, curiosity, and communication
  3. Value Side Projects: As Boris Cherny (Claude Code creator) discovered, side projects often reveal true capability better than resume credentials

For Current Engineers Looking to Level Up

Section titled “For Current Engineers Looking to Level Up”
  1. Pick One AI Tool and Master It: Whether it’s Claude Code, Cursor, or GitHub Copilot, deep expertise beats broad familiarity
  2. Practice Explaining Technical Concepts: Start a blog, give internal talks, or mentor juniors
  3. Take Ownership of Something End-to-End: Volunteer for a project where you’re responsible from design to production

The Future is Human + AI

Section titled “The Future is Human + AI”

The AI Software Engineer of 2025 isn’t someone who competes with AI—they’re someone who orchestrates AI to achieve outcomes neither could accomplish alone.

The job posting we analyzed gets it exactly right: technical competence is the baseline. What separates exceptional candidates from merely qualified ones are those six qualities that no AI can replicate:

  • Responsibility that drives outcomes
  • Curiosity that fuels innovation
  • Execution that ships products
  • Planning that manages complexity
  • Communication that multiplies impact
  • Adaptability that ensures longevity

The future belongs to engineers who embrace AI as a partner while cultivating the irreplaceable human qualities that make great software possible.
