🎚️ CodexBar: macOS Menu Bar Usage Stats for Claude Code & OpenAI Codex

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

CodexBar is a tiny macOS 15+ menu bar app created by Peter Steinberger (@steipete) that keeps your AI coding assistant usage limits always visible. Monitor both OpenAI Codex and Claude Code limits - including 5-hour session windows and weekly caps - without logging into any dashboard.

  • Dual provider support: Track both Codex (5h/weekly + credits) and Claude Code (session/weekly + Sonnet-only limits) simultaneously
  • Zero login required: Reads directly from local CLI output - no passwords, no browser sessions needed
  • Real-time visibility: See remaining tokens, reset timers, and account info from your menu bar

🧩 Why You Need Usage Monitoring

Section titled “🧩 Why You Need Usage Monitoring”

If you’re actively using Claude Code or OpenAI Codex for development, you’ve likely hit rate limits unexpectedly. Here’s why CodexBar is essential:

  1. Avoid workflow interruptions Know your remaining quota before starting a major coding session. No more “rate limited” surprises in the middle of complex refactoring.

  2. Track multiple time windows Both services use overlapping 5-hour and weekly windows. CodexBar visualizes both so you understand exactly when limits reset.

  3. Monitor Sonnet-only limits (Claude) Claude Code’s Sonnet model has its own weekly cap. CodexBar shows this separately so you can strategically choose when to use which model.

  4. Credits visibility (Codex) See your paid credits balance alongside rate limits. Know when you’re burning through free tier vs. paid usage.

⚙️ Installation

Section titled “⚙️ Installation”

Homebrew (Recommended)

Section titled “Homebrew (Recommended)”

Update via:

Manual Download

Section titled “Manual Download”

Download the ready-to-run zip from GitHub Releases.

🔧 Requirements

Section titled “🔧 Requirements”
  • macOS 15+ (Sequoia or later)
  • For Codex: Codex CLI ≥ 0.55.0 installed and logged in
  • For Claude Code: Claude CLI installed via claude --version and logged in via claude login

CodexBar auto-detects installed CLIs on first launch:

  • Codex enabled by default
  • Claude turns on automatically when claude binary is present

🚀 How It Works

Section titled “🚀 How It Works”

Reading Claude Code Usage

Section titled “Reading Claude Code Usage”

CodexBar runs claude /usage and claude /status in a local PTY (pseudo-terminal) to extract:

  • Session usage percentage
  • Weekly usage percentage
  • Sonnet-only weekly limit
  • Reset countdown timers
  • Account email, organization, and login method

Privacy note: Everything stays local. No network calls beyond what the Claude CLI itself makes.

Reading Codex Usage

Section titled “Reading Codex Usage”

CodexBar prefers the Codex app-server RPC for rate limits and credits. Falls back to PTY scrape of codex /status if RPC unavailable.

Optional “Access OpenAI via web” setting adds:

  • Code review remaining
  • Usage breakdown
  • Credits usage history

This reuses existing signed-in chatgpt.com session via Safari/Chrome cookie import - no passwords stored.

📊 Visual Status Indicators

Section titled “📊 Visual Status Indicators”

The menu bar icon uses a clever two-bar system:

BarWhat It Shows
Top bar5-hour window quota (or credits bar if weekly exhausted)
Bottom barWeekly window quota (thin line)

Icon variants:

  • Codex mode: Features the signature “eyelid blink” design
  • Claude mode: Shows Claude’s notch/leg variant
  • Errors/unknowns: Icon dims (no confusing text)

⚡ Refresh Options

Section titled “⚡ Refresh Options”

Menu → “Refresh every…” offers these presets:

  • Manual only
  • 1 minute
  • 2 minutes
  • 5 minutes (default)
  • 15 minutes

Manual mode still allows on-demand “Refresh now” from the menu.

🛡️ Privacy & Security

Section titled “🛡️ Privacy & Security”

CodexBar is designed with privacy in mind:

  • No disk scanning - See issue #12 for audit notes
  • Per-provider data isolation - Claude info never mixes with Codex info
  • Local CLI reading only - Account details come directly from CLI output
  • No password storage - Optional web access uses existing browser cookies

🔗 Related Tools

Section titled “🔗 Related Tools”

CodexBar is part of a suite of developer productivity tools from steipete:

ToolDescription
TrimmyFlatten multi-line shell snippets for paste-and-run
MCPorterTypeScript toolkit + CLI for MCP servers

Inspiration: ccusage - CLI tool for Claude Code usage cost tracking (which we’ve covered previously).

📝 Known Limitations

Section titled “📝 Known Limitations”
ScenarioBehavior
No Codex usage yetShows “No usage yet” - run one prompt and refresh
Claude CLI missingShows “Claude CLI is not installed”
Not logged inShows respective login error
Reset time parsing failsSurfaces raw text when timezone info missing

✍️ Summary

Section titled “✍️ Summary”

CodexBar solves a real pain point for heavy AI coding assistant users:

  • ✅ See both Codex and Claude Code limits at a glance
  • ✅ Monitor 5-hour sessions AND weekly windows
  • ✅ Track Sonnet-specific limits and paid credits
  • ✅ Zero login required - reads local CLI data
  • ✅ Privacy-first design with no disk scanning

Install it via brew install --cask steipete/tap/codexbar and never be surprised by rate limits again.

📌 Want more Claude Code tips, usage optimization strategies, and AI developer tools? Follow our channel for the latest guides on maximizing your AI-assisted development workflow!

Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web

Section titled “Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web”

🦞 EXFOLIATE! EXFOLIATE! — That’s the playful battlecry of Clawdis, an open-source personal AI assistant created by Peter Steinberger (@steipete). Unlike cloud-hosted AI services, Clawdis runs on your own devices, connecting to the messaging platforms you already use daily: WhatsApp, Telegram, and Web.

What is Clawdis?

Section titled “What is Clawdis?”

Clawdis is a local-first control plane for your personal AI assistant. Think of it as the infrastructure that lets you interact with an AI agent through:

  • WhatsApp — Send a message, get an intelligent response
  • Telegram — Bot-based conversations via the Telegram Bot API
  • WebChat — Browser-based interface for desktop use
  • macOS app — Menu bar control with voice wake and push-to-talk
  • iOS node — Canvas surface with voice trigger forwarding

The name “Clawdis” is a clever portmanteau: CLAW + TARDIS — because every space lobster needs a time-and-space machine!

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Multi-Surface Inbox

Section titled “1. Multi-Surface Inbox”

Clawdis brings your AI assistant to wherever you already communicate. No need to switch to a dedicated app — just message from WhatsApp or Telegram, and your assistant responds.

2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk

Section titled “2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk”

On macOS and iOS, Clawdis supports:

  • Voice wake — Say the wake word and start talking
  • Push-to-talk overlay — Quick voice interactions
  • Local speech recognition — Privacy-preserving, on-device processing

3. Live Canvas

Section titled “3. Live Canvas”

A visual workspace that you can control from the agent. The Canvas renders live content and supports A2UI (Agent-to-UI) communication for rich interactive experiences.

4. Automation-Ready

Section titled “4. Automation-Ready”

Clawdis comes with built-in capabilities for:

  • Browser control — Automate web interactions
  • Media handling — Process images, audio, and video
  • Tool streaming — Real-time tool execution feedback
  • Smart home integration — Philips Hue, Eight Sleep, and more

5. Local-First Architecture

Section titled “5. Local-First Architecture”

The Gateway (control plane) owns all state and runs locally. Everything else — nodes, surfaces, and integrations — connects to it:

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Node.js 22+
  • pnpm package manager

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Configuration

Section titled “Configuration”

Create ~/.clawdis/clawdis.json:

Chat Commands

Section titled “Chat Commands”

Use these commands in WhatsApp, Telegram, or WebChat:

CommandDescription
/statusHealth and session info
/new or /resetReset the session
/think <level>Set thinking level (off/minimal/low/medium/high)
/verbose on/offToggle verbose mode
/restartRestart the gateway (owner-only)
/activation mention/alwaysGroup activation toggle

Meet Clawd: The Space Lobster

Section titled “Meet Clawd: The Space Lobster”

Clawdis was built for Clawd 🦞, Peter Steinberger’s AI assistant. Clawd is described as:

“Claude with a ‘w’ and a lobster emoji.”

Running on Claude Opus 4.5 from a Mac Studio in Vienna, Clawd embodies four core values:

  1. Pragmatic Helpfulness — Focus on efficient problem-solving
  2. Honest & Direct — Candid feedback, willing to disagree
  3. Friendship — Collaborative partnership, not just a tool
  4. Learn & Grow — Embrace mistakes as learning opportunities

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

Daily Workflow Assistant

Section titled “Daily Workflow Assistant”
  • Send a WhatsApp message: “Ship checklist for my iOS app”
  • Clawd checks your project, runs tests, and reports status

Smart Home Control

Section titled “Smart Home Control”
  • “Turn off all lights except the bedroom”
  • “Set the bedroom temperature to 68°F”

Email Triage

Section titled “Email Triage”

Agent Workspace & Skills

Section titled “Agent Workspace & Skills”

Clawdis supports a skill-based architecture:

  • Workspace root: ~/clawd (configurable)
  • Injected prompts: AGENTS.md, SOUL.md, TOOLS.md
  • Skills directory: ~/clawd/skills/<skill>/SKILL.md

macOS App

Section titled “macOS App”

The macOS app is the command center:

  • Menu bar control for Gateway health
  • Voice Wake with push-to-talk overlay
  • WebChat and debug tools
  • Remote gateway control over SSH

Build and run:

Security Considerations

Section titled “Security Considerations”
  • Allowlisting: Restrict who can interact with your assistant via routing.allowFrom
  • Local-first: Gateway runs on 127.0.0.1 by default
  • Credentials storage: WhatsApp session stored in ~/.clawdis/credentials
  • Bridge security: Optional TCP bridge with pairing for mobile nodes

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?

Section titled “Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?”

Clawdis is agent-agnostic but was designed around Pi (an RPC-based agent runtime) and commonly uses Claude models. You can configure your preferred AI provider.

Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?”

Clawdis is designed as a single-user, personal assistant. For multi-user scenarios, you’d need to run separate instances.

Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?

Section titled “Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?”

Clawdis uses the WhatsApp Web protocol via Baileys. Use responsibly and at your own risk.

Q: How do I add custom skills?

Section titled “Q: How do I add custom skills?”

Create a new folder in ~/clawd/skills/<skill-name>/ with a SKILL.md file describing the skill’s capabilities and instructions.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

WhatsApp connection issues

Section titled “WhatsApp connection issues”

Gateway won’t start

Section titled “Gateway won’t start”

Check if port 18789 is in use:

iOS node won’t connect

Section titled “iOS node won’t connect”

Ensure the Bridge is running and both devices are on the same network.

Clawdis represents an exciting approach to personal AI assistants — local-first, multi-platform, and deeply integrated with your daily communication tools. If you’re looking for a private, always-on AI companion that respects your data sovereignty while delivering powerful capabilities, give Clawdis a try.
